metadata.title: Experimental investigation of fracture properties of asphalt mixtures modified with Nano Fe2O3 and carbon nanotubes

Experimental investigation of fracture properties of asphalt mixtures modified with Nano Fe2O3 and carbon nanotubes
S. Pirmohammad∗, Y. Majd-Shokorlou and B. Amani
Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, University of Mohaghegh Ardabili, Ardabil, Iran
(Received 10 October 2018; accepted 2 April 2019 )
This paper investigates the effect of Nano Fe2O3 and CNTs (carbon nanotubes) on fracture properties of HMA (hot mix asphalt) mixtures subjected to mixed mode I and II loading. Semicircular bend (SCB) specimens were used for performing fracture experiments. Four different percentages (i.e. 0.1%, 0.4%, 0.8% and 1.2%) of Nano Fe2O3 and CNTs were individually mixed with the same base binder to provide two different nanomaterial modified mixtures (i.e. Nano Fe2O3 and CNTs modified HMA mixtures). Both the Nano Fe2O3 and CNTs were found to improve fracture properties of HMA mixtures remarkably; however, the fracture strength of HMA mixtures was more improved by CNTs than Nano Fe2O3. Generally, the highest improvement in fracture resistance achieved by utilisation of these nanomaterials is observed when the specimens are loaded under pure mode I (i.e. 27% and 46% for the Nano Fe2O3 and CNTs modified HMA mixtures, respectively), and as the amount of shear mode (mode II) at the crack front increases, the improvement effect of Nano Fe2O3 and CNTs on the fracture resistance reduces gradually. The results also demonstrate that the appropriate percentage of Nano Fe2O3 and CNTs for modifying HMA mixtures is 0.8% and 1.2%, respectively.
Keywords: HMA mixtures; mixed mode I/II; Nano Fe2O3 and CNTs; fracture resistance

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Previous investigations exhibit that the roads paved by asphalt materials may experience different deteriorations like cracking, rutting, shoving, etc. These distresses reduce both the life and safety of roads. They also enhance maintenance and rehabilitation costs. Therefore, previous studies have been focused on reducing or retarding the mentioned distresses. Investigations show that thermal cracking is one of the major modes of failure in asphalt overlays served in the cold regions. Traffic loads often accelerate the cracks created by thermal cracking, and cold climate makes asphalt materials to exhibit brittle manner at low temperatures. Hence, many researchers used linear elastic fracture mechanics (LEFM) concept to explore fracture properties of HMA (hot mix asphalt) concretes at low-temperature conditions (see e.g. Dongre, Sharma, & Anderson, 1989; Kim, Kweon, Doh, & Park, 2003; Marasteanu, Dai, Labuz, & Li, 2002; Tekalur, Shukla, Sadd, & Lee, 2009).
Extensive investigations can be found in the literature studding the fracture behaviour of asphalt mixtures. For example, Aliha, Behbahani, Fazaeli, and Rezaifar (2014), Pirmohammad, Khoramishad, and Ayatollahi (2015) and Pirmohammad and Ayatollahi (2015) investigated the effect of binder type and air void content on the fracture resistance of asphalt mixtures
*Corresponding author. Email: s_pirmohammad@uma.ac.ir
© 2019 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group
under different loading modes. Their results exhibited the remarkable effect of asphalt concrete components on the low-temperature cracking behaviour of mixtures. According to an investigation performed by Aliha (2019) on the mode II fracture toughness of different asphalt mixtures, the mode II fracture toughness of asphalt mixtures (i.e. KIIc) are approximately 0.9–1.1 times the corresponding value of KIc. In another study, Fakhri, Kharrazi, and Aliha (2018) characterised fracture energy of different asphalt mixtures. They concluded that lime aggregate has higher fracture resistance than silica aggregate at low temperatures, while their fracture resistance is approximately the same at intermediate temperatures. Pirmohammad and Kiani (2016a, 2016b) investigated fracture resistance of asphalt mixtures at variable temperature conditions. According to their results, the asphalt mixtures are more vulnerable to crack growth at variable temperature conditions than variable temperature conditions. Aliha and Fattahi Amirdehi (2017) characterised fracture toughness of asphalt mixtures containing different air void contents using Weibull statistical method. Ayatollahi and Pirmohammad (2013, 2014) investigated the effect of loading modes at low temperatures. According to their investigations, the fracture toughness initially increases and then reduces with a decrease in the temperature. Behbahani, Aliha, Fazaeli, and Aghajani (2013) investigated the effect of different additives such as poly phosphoric acid, styrene butadiene styrene, anti-striping agent, crumb rubber and FT-paraffin wax (Sasobit) on the fracture toughness of asphalt mixtures. Their results show that all the additives improve the fracture toughness of asphalt mixtures, and the highest improvement is achieved by using sasobit and crumb rubber. Aliha, Fakhri, Kharrazi, and Berto (2018) studied the effect of aggregate type and air void on the fracture energy at different temperatures. Aliha, Razmi, and Mansourian (2017) studied the influence of natural and synthetic fibres on fracture resistance of warm mix asphalt (WMA) concretes. The results showed that fibres can significantly improve the fracture resistance of asphalt mixtures. Fakhri, Amoosoltani, and Aliha (2017) investigated the effects of aggregate gradation, cement content, reclaimed asphalt pavement (RAP) and rubber content on the mode I and mode II fracture toughness. The results demonstrated that concrete mix specifications had a significant effect on the cracking initiation of roller compacted concrete (RCC). On the other hand, some interesting investigations have been performed on the mixed mode I/III loading. For example, Ayatollahi, Pirmohammad, and Sedighiani (2014) and Ameri, Mansourian, Khavas, Aliha, and Ayatollahi (2011) showed that the mode III loading cab be a serious threat for the asphalt concrete fracture when a vehicle is positioned at special distances relative to the crack plane. Investigations performed by Aliha, Bahmani, and Akhondi (2016), Pirmohammad and Bayat (2016a, 2016b, 2017), Pirmohammad and Kiani (2016c) and Mansourian, Hashemi, and Aliha (2018) demonstrated that the fracture resistance reduces with increase in the mode III deformations occurred at the crack front.
Many fracture criteria have been also developed in the past years to theoretically predict the fracture behaviour of different engineering materials under mixed mode I/II loading. Maximum tangential stress (suggested by Erdogan & Sih, 1963), generalised maximum tangential stress (suggested by Smith, Ayatollahi, & Pavier, 2001), maximum energy release rate (suggested by Irwin, 1957) and strain energy density (suggested by Sih, 1974) are some to mention a few. For example, Ayatollahi and Aliha (2008) employed the generalised maximum tangential stress criterion for predicting the mixed mode fracture toughness of rock materials tested with the Brazilian disc specimen. The results showed that this criterion provides significantly improved predictions for the experimental data. Aliha, Ayatollahi, and Akbardoost (2012) obtained fracture toughness of Harsin marble using Brazilian disc and SCB specimens. The results indicated that the generalised maximum tangential stress criterion, which regards the effects of geometry and loading conditions, can provide individual fracture curves for theses specimens with very good estimates for the test results. Mirsayar, Berto, Aliha, and Park (2016), Aliha, Mahdavi, and Ayatollahi (2017) and Mirsayar, Razmi, Aliha, and Berto (2018) evaluated the extended maximum
tangential strain (EMTSN) criterion on the experimental data for the rock materials. The results showed that the EMTSN criterion is capable of successfully estimating the fracture resistance of rock materials. According to Razavi, Aliha, and Berto (2018) and Aliha, Berto, Mousavi, and Razavi (2017), average strain energy density (ASED) criterion is able to provide well predictions for the fracture behaviour of rock materials. Berto and Gomez (2017) suggested two procedures including the strain energy density (SED) over a control volume and the cohesive zone model (CZM) to evaluate fracture resistance of notched components. The good agreement between theory and experimental results adds further confidence to the proposed fracture criteria.
Nanomaterials are able to improve the mechanical properties of asphalt mixtures (Faramarzi, Arabani, Haghi, & Mottaghitalab, 2015). Recently, application of nanomaterials such as Nano silicon dioxide and Nano titanium (Ye & Chen, 2009), Nano zinc oxide (Sadeghnejad, Arabani, Shakeri, & Mirabdolazimi, 2013), Nano clay (Jahromi & Khodaii, 2009), carbon nanofibres (Khattak, Khattab, Rizvi, & Zhang, 2012), etc. has been widely increased. For example, Shafabakhsh and Ani (2015) showed that the addition of Nano TiO2 and Nano SiO2 to the asphalt mixtures boosts the binder rheological characteristics, and improves their rutting and fatigue resistance. The research carried out by Ashish, Singh, and Bohm (2016) showed that Nano clays improve moisture damage resistivity and rutting resistivity, and also enhance fatigue life of HMA mixtures. Zhang, Su, Zhao, Zhang, and Zhang (2016) employed combinations of nanoparticles and polymers (namely Nano-ZnO, Nano-TiO2, Nano-CaCO3, SBS and SBR) as binder modifiers to simultaneously improve the high- and low-temperature properties of binders. Amin, El-Badawy, Breakah, and Ibrahim (2016) investigated the effect of CNTs (carbon nanotubes) on the binder characteristics. They concluded that resistance of both unaged and aged binders against the rutting increases with increase in the CNTs percentage, and also the fatigue resistance is improved by increasing the CNTs content in the binder. Arabani and Faramarzi (2015) made an interesting investigation on the effect of CNTs. They found that the CNTs prevent the generation and propagation of the tensile cracks, and also the fatigue behaviour of CNTs-modified binders is significantly improved. In another study, Ziari, Farahani, Goli, and Sadeghpour Galooyak (2014) used CNTs as the binder modifier. According to their study, this additive improves different properties of HMA mixtures such as penetration degree, complex modulus, fatigue and rutting resistance. Based on an investigation carried out by Xiao, Amirkhanian, and Amirkhanian (2011), application of CNTs improves the fatigue resistance, rutting resistance and linear viscoelastic response of binder. Ameri, Nowbakht, Molayem, and Aliha (2016) investigated the effect of CNTs on the fatigue and fracture properties of HMA concretes. They found that the CNTs enhance the fracture and fatigue properties of asphalt mixtures particularly at higher CNTs percentages. Kordi and Shafabakhsh (2017) added Nano Fe2O3 to the HMA mixtures, and demonstrated that this nanomaterial can improve the mechanical properties, fatigue and rutting resistance of HMA mixtures to an acceptable level.
Although there are many papers concerning the effect of nanomaterials on performance characteristics of HMA mixtures, as mentioned above; nevertheless, there are very few investigations concerning the effect of nanomaterials on fracture behaviour of HMA mixtures. Therefore, this research aimed at studying the fracture behaviour of Nano Fe2O3 and CNTs modified HMA mixtures.

sections.heading: 2. Test specimen and finite element analyses
sections.text:
Disk-shaped compact tension (DC-T), single edge notched beam (SENB), semi-circular bend (SCB) are frequently used by researchers for investigating fracture behaviour of asphalt materials (see e.g. Arabani & Ferdowsi, 2009; Mohammad, Kabir, & Saadeh, 2008; Tekalur et al.,
2009; Wagnoner, Buttlar, & Paulino, 2005). Furthermore, some researchers like Aliha, Bahmani, and Akhondi (2015), Aliah et al. (2016), Aliha, Razmi, and Mousavi (2018), Aliha, Sarbijan, and Bahmani (2017), Pirmohammad and Bayat (2016a, 2016b, 2017) and Pirmohammad and Mengharpey (2018) employed a disc-shaped specimen to characterise mixed mode fracture toughness of asphalt concretes. As a popular specimen, the SCB has been used by many researchers during the past years. For example, Ayatollahi and Aliha (2007) numerically studied the conventional SCB specimen with an inclined edge crack, which produces all combinations of mode I and mode II loading. In another study, Ameri, Mansourian, Pirmohammad, Aliha, and Ayatollahi (2012) suggested novel SCB specimens with a straight edge crack subjected to three-point bend loading. In these specimens, the mode mixity is controlled by locations of the bottom supports. Mirsayar, Shi, and Zollinger (2017) developed the SCB specimen to investigate the bond strength between asphalt concrete and Portland cement concrete. Aliha, Heidari-Rarani, Shokrieh, and Ayatollahi (2012) used SCB specimen for investigating fracture behaviour of polymer concretes.
Since the geometry of HMA samples produced by gyratory compactor is cylindrical; hence, the geometry of semi-circle was chosen for producing the test specimens in this research study. According to Figure 1, the SCB specimen contains a vertical edge crack, which all mode mixities from pure mode I to pure mode II can be provided by simply shifting the crack with respect to middle of the specimen (or by changing the value of L). Meanwhile, the SCB specimen is asymmetrically loaded by a three-point bend fixture, and parameters S1 and S2 refer to the position of the lower supports, as shown in Figure 1.
In order to find the fracture toughness of materials, calculation of geometry constants is necessary. The geometry constants are obtained by performing finite element analyses on the selected test specimen. Hence, in the current research to find the geometry constants, threedimensional finite analyses were carried out on the SCB specimen using nonlinear finite element code ABAQUS. In the finite element analyses, mechanical properties of a typical asphalt mixture, geometrical values and load were considered as: elasticity modulus E = 12.5 GPa, Poisson’s ratio υ = 0.35, circle radius R = 50 mm, specimen thickness t = 25 mm, crack length a = 18 mm and applied force P = 1000 N. A total number of about 72,000 solid brick elements (i.e. C3D20R) were employed in the finite element analyses. In order to produce a square root
singularity of stress field, singular (i.e. quarter point) elements were utilised at the first ring of finite elements surrounding the crack front. Additionally, the elements near the crack front were built fine enough with the bias ratio of 5 along the radial direction to precisely compute the crack parameters, while coarser elements were built in the regions away from the crack tip. The mesh pattern used in the finite element models is shown in Figure 2. The stress intensity factors (K I and K II) obtained from the finite element analyses were placed into the following equations to calculate the mode I and mode II geometry constants (YI and YII).
YI = KI√ πa 2Rt P , (1.a)
YII = KII√ πa 2Rt P . (1.b)
Table 1 presents the results of geometry constants (YI and YII), crack position (L) and location of the lower supports (S1 and S2). The parameter Me states the relative contributions of mode I and mode II, which is defined as:
M e = 2 π
tan−1 (
KI KII
) , (2)
where the value of Me is 1 and 0, respectively for the pure mode I and the pure mode II, while Me is between 1 and 0 for the case of mixed mode I and II.
It is worth mentioning that in the calculations of mode I and mode II geometry constants given in Table 1, the mechanical properties including elasticity modulus and Poisson’s ratio as well as the applied force are only required to obtain the stress intensity factors (K I and K II) using
the finite element analyses. But, YI and YII are independent from the material properties and the applied force, and they are only influenced by the geometry specifications of the test specimen such as radius, thickness, crack length and span (more details have been given in Pirmohammad & Bayat, 2017). Therefore, the mode I and mode II fracture toughness of asphalt mixtures measured in the present research study are independent from the elastic modulus, Poisson’s ratio and the applied force considered in the finite element simulations.
It is worth noting that Ayatollahi, Aliha, and Saghafi (2011) performed many finite element analyses on a novel SCB specimen containing an edge crack at the middle, which is loading asymmetrically. This specimen can produce different mixed mode I/II loadings by changing the location of supports, whereas the position of the crack is fixed at the middle. The specimen used by Ayatollahi et al. (2011) and that used in this study is different in terms of type of producing mixed mode I/II loading; however, both of these specimens are the same for producing the pure mode I loading. They calculated the mode I geometry constant as YI = 4.05 for the case of S1/S2 = 2/3 and a/R = 0.33. While, it has been computed as YI = 4.29 for the case of S1/S2 = 2/3 and a/R = 0.36 in this research study, as shown in Table 1. The small discrepancy between the results can be attributed to the fact that they obtained the values of geometry constants by performing 2D finite element analyses, while 3D finite element simulations have been employed in this research study to calculate the values of geometry constants.

sections.heading: 3. Materials and specimen preparation
sections.text:
As is well known, the asphalt mixtures are mainly composed of binder, aggregate and air void. Binder with penetration grade of 60/70 and PG64–22 was used in the present research as a base binder for preparing the HMA mixtures. Table 2 presents physical properties of the base binder. Aggregate gradation No. 5 shown in Table 3 was employed in this research based on the Iran Highway Asphalt Paving Code. The nominal maximum aggregate size was selected 12.5 mm for preparing the HMA mixtures; because, the nominal maximum aggregate size must be smaller than the specimen dimensions (namely radius and thickness of the SCB specimen) to correctly determine the HMA characteristics, as proposed in Pérez-Jiménez, Botella, Moon, and Marasteanu (2013) and Timm, Birgisson, and Newcomb (1998).
Three different asphalt mixtures were prepared in the current task. The first type contained the base binder, which is called control HMA mixture. The second and third types contained the same base binder but modified with Nano Fe2O3 and CNTs, respectively. Properties of these nanomaterials have been presented in Tables 4 and 5. It is pointed out that all the HMA mixtures considered in the current task had the same aggregate gradation (namely No. 5) and air void content of 4%. The aggregate gradation No. 5 used in this research for preparing the HMA mixtures was within the range proposed by Iran Highway Asphalt Paving Code (IHAPC-234). Furthermore, standard Marshall mix design procedure was used to design the HMA mixtures.
In order to prepare modified HMA samples in this experimental study, particles of the Nano Fe2O3 and CNTs were initially added to the base binder, and the blend of them was then mixed together by a shear mixer working at a speed of 1800 rpm for 1 h to achieve a suitable homogeneity. Figure 3 displays the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of the base binder modified with 1.2% Nano Fe2O3. As seen in this figure, the Nano particles have been suitably dispersed within the binder’s mixture without generation of agglomerates. It is pointed out that during the mixing process, the temperature was set at 120°C using a hot plate device similar to the other researches (see e.g. Amin et al., 2016). Meanwhile, particles of Nano Fe2O3 and CNTs with four different percentages of 0.1%, 0.4%, 0.8% and 1.2% (by weight of the base binder) were mixed with the base binder.
Cylindrical samples with 100 mm in diameter and 60 mm in height were compacted in the laboratory. The cylindrical samples were sliced into two discs of radius 50 mm and thickness 25 mm using a water-cooled masonry sawing machine with a blade having 4 mm thickness. The discs were then halved to provide semi-circles using another water-cooled cutting machine. A crack was eventually created within the semi-circles in an appropriate situation given in Table 1 using the mentioned water-cooled cutting machine with a thin blade having a thickness of 0.3 mm.
It is worth noting that the size of the SCB specimen was selected by considering a fact that the
size of the test specimen must be three to four times greater than the maximum aggregate size, as recommended by others (see e.g. Romero & Masad, 2001; Wagnoner et al., 2005) for avoiding the size effects. In this research, the ratio of the SCB radius to the maximum aggregate size is 4, which falls within the recommended range.

sections.heading: 4. Fracture test set-up
sections.text: Fracture experiments on the SCB specimens, made of three different HMA mixtures described above, were carried out to characterise their fracture resistance. Before performing the experiments, the SCB specimens were conditioned at a constant temperature of − 15°C in a

freezer for 6 h to ensure all parts of the specimens have the same temperature. The SCB specimen was then put upon the lower supports of the universal test machine (i.e. UTM with a capacity of 15 ton) in accordance with the results of finite element analyses presented in Table 1. Afterwards, the upper fixture having a speed of 3 mm/min moved downwards to load the SCB specimen. Figure 4 displays the fracture test set-up for conducting the experiments. It is noticed that the lower supports were adjusted at S1 = 33mm and S2 = 33 mm for the pure mode I and S1 = 33mm and S2 = 13 mm for the pure mode II and mixed mode I/II experiments (see Table 1). It is reminded that the SCB specimens contained a crack at a proper location (i.e. L) given in Table 1 for any loading mode. Variations of load versus displacement were finally recorded from the fracture experiments. Figure 5 plots variations of the load versus displacement (as examples) recorded from the experiments, in which the load initially increases to reach its peak value, and once the specimen fractures, the load suddenly reduces. This indicates that the fracture of SCB specimens has been taken place according to the LEFM concept. Therefore, the stress intensity factors (SIFs) can be correctly used to describe the fracture phenomenon. In order to calculate the values of SIFs, peak load Pcr must be obtained from the load–displacement curve. Table 6 lists the values of Pcr for the asphalt concretes investigated in the current task. These values of Pcr were then placed into the following equations to calculate the critical SIFs:
KIf = YI Pcr2Rt √ πa, (3a)
KIIf = YII Pcr2Rt √ πa, (3b)
Keff = √ K2If + K2IIf, (3c)
where YI and YII are the mode I and mode II geometry constants listed in Table 1. Additionally, K If and K IIf refer to the mode I and mode II critical SIFs, respectively. Meanwhile, Keff is called effective critical SIF, which represents the fracture resistance of HMA mixture subjected to any
loading mode. It is pointed out that Keff reduces to K If (or K IIf) when the SCB specimen is subjected to pure mode I (or pure mode II).

sections.heading: 5. Experimental results and discussions
sections.text:
Fracture tests on the Nano Fe2O3 and CNTs modified HMA mixtures were conducted under different mixed mode I/II loadings at a temperature of − 15°C, as described above. The critical SIFs calculated for these HMA mixtures are shown in Tables 7–9. The effect of these nanomaterials on fracture properties of the asphalt concretes is discussed below in detail.
5.1. Effect of Nano Fe2O3 Figure 6 shows fracture resistance of the Nano Fe2O3-modified HMA mixtures. As the percentage of Nano Fe2O3 in the HMA mixture increases, the fracture resistance initially increases to reach its peak value at the percentage of 0.8%, and then reduces for all loading modes. This signifies that there is an optimum value for utilisation of the Nano Fe2O3 as a modifier in HMA mixtures. Hence, the percentage of 0.8% is the suitable value for addition of the Nano Fe2O3 to asphalt mixtures. Similar results have been reported by Kordi and Shafabakhsh (2017). According to their investigation, addition of 0.9% Nano Fe2O3 to the stone mastic asphalt mixtures showed the best results for the mechanical properties (including stiffness modulus and resistance to fatigue cracking) of the mixture; while, utilisation of higher percentages of Nano Fe2O3 aggravated performance of the mixtures. Indeed, the Nano Fe2O3 helps the binder particles to generate higher adhesion feature, and therfore the aggregates are strongly bonded together, and the SCB samples with stronger adhesive factor, either at low temperatures or high temperatures, demonstrate more suitable performance.

According to Figure 7, addition of the Nano Fe2O3 increases fracture strength of the HMA mixtures subjected to the pure mode I and the mixed mode I/II (Me = 0.66 and 0.32) loadings. The significant improvement of 32% in fracture strength is achieved by the addition of 0.8% Fe2O3 under mixed mode loading of Me = 0.66. According to Figure 7, an improvement of 13% to 27% for the mode I, 8% to 32% for the mixed mode of Me = 0.66 and 3% to 11% for the mixed mode of Me = 0.32 is generally observed depending on the percentage of Nano Fe2O3 used in the HMA mixture. Moreover, based on the results shown in Figure 7, the Nano Fe2O3 has a negligible or negative effect on the pure mode II fracture strength of the asphalt concretes. This indicates that the Nano Fe2O3 had no improvement in bonding between the aggregates in the shear planes, which led to insignificant influence on fracture strength of the asphalt concretes. It is also noticed that for the case of pure mode II, the best improvement in fracture strength is 5% for the HMA mixture containing 0.8% Nano Fe2O3 among those modified by Nano Fe2O3.
Hence, one may conclude that by addition of 0.8% Nano Fe2O3 to the HMA mixture, the fracture strength is improved by 5% to 32% depending on the mode of loading.
5.2. Effect of CNTs Because of outstanding mechanical properties of CNTs, they have a great deal of potential to improve performance of HMA mixtures compared with previously used materials such as glass or carbon fibres (Bai & Allaoui, 2003; Treacy, Ebbesen, & Gibson, 1996). In addition, other interesting properties of CNTs like high aspect ratio, specific strength, chemical resistance, electrical
and thermal conductivity make them as a popular binder modifier (Chong & Garboczi, 2002; Makar & Beaudoin, 2004).
Figure 8 displays results of fracture tests conducted on the CNTs-modified HMA mixtures under different loading modes of I, II and mixed I/II. According to Figure 8, by increasing the percentage of CNTs within the HMA mixture, fracture strength increases. Furthermore, control HMA mixture has the least fracture strength compared with CNTs-modified HMA mixtures. Hence, utilisation of the CNTs improves the fracture strength of HMA mixtures. Because, Nano modified binder is usually more viscous than the unmodified binders and tends to exhibit improved adhesive bonding for aggregating the particles. In addition, better interlock between Nano modified binders and aggregates strengthens the mixture and leads to improve the fracture resistance (Shafabakhsh & Ani, 2015). It is also pointed out that a similar trend has been observed by other researchers when using CNTs as a binder modifier. For example, Arabani and Faramarzi (2015) reported that the resistance against permanent deformation and fatigue behaviour are improved by increasing CNTs content. In another study carried out by Ameri et al. (2016), fracture and fatigue properties of asphalt mixtures are improved particularly at higher CNTs percentages.
The amount of improvement achieved by the addition of the CNTs to HMA mixtures is shown in Figure 7, in which the fracture strength increases for any loading mode. This improvement in fracture strength is more highlighted when the SCB specimens are subjected to the pure mode I or the mixed mode I/II loadings that the contribution of mode I is dominant at the crack front. In other words, as the amount of shear mode at the crack front increases (from pure mode I to pure mode II), the improvement effect of CNTs on the fracture resistance reduces gradually. The highest increase in fracture strength (namely 46%) is achieved for the HMA mixtures modified
by 1.2% CNTs under pure mode I. According to Figure 7, an improvement of 20% to 46% for the pure mode I, 14% to 38% for the mixed mode of Me = 0.66, 3% to 20% for the mixed mode of Me = 0.32 and 0% to 11% for the pure mode II is achieved depending on the CNTs content available in the HMA mixture. Meanwhile, although the Nano Fe2O3 increases fracture resistance of HMA mixtures significantly; however, the fracture strength of HMA mixtures is more improved by the CNTs than the Nano Fe2O3 for the same percentage used in the mixture, as shown in Figure 7.
The fracture toughness of different asphalt mixtures vary between 0.6 and 1.2 MPa m0.5 (according to Aliha & Sarbijan, 2016), and the fracture toughness obtained in this research for
the mixtures modified with nanomaterials is between 0.67 and 1.15 MPa m0.5 depending on the nanomaterial type and its content as well as type of loading; consequently, the results obtained in this research are within the typical range found by other researchers. Hence, the results of this research can be concluded to be valid.
5.3. Effect of loading mode Figure 9 shows the effect of the type of loading on the fracture strength of modified mixtures studied in this research. According to Figure 9, by enhancing the amount of mode II, fracture
strength of both the modified HMA mixtures initially decreases to reach its minimum at the loading mode of Me = 0.32, and then increases. This implies that the HMA mixtures modified with nanomaterials are more vulnerable to the mixed mode fracture than the pure mode one. Hence, HMA pavements are exposed to the critical conditions of crack growth under the mixed mode I/II loading (i.e. Me = 0.32). Another point from the results shown in Figure 9 is that the mode of loading affects the fracture resistance of HMA mixtures modified with nanomaterials
mostly under pure mode I, and this effect reduces as the shear mode is added to the mode I. The similar results have been observed by Aliha, Razmi, et al., (2017). Their results reveal that the effect of both the Jute and FORTA fibres on improving the fracture resistance of WMA concretes is more pronounced for loading cases with a greater proportion of mode I. In other words, when the proportion of mode II becomes dominant at the crack tip, none of the fibres had a sound effect on the fracture resistance.
Figure 10 displays the SCB specimens made of Nano Fe2O3 (or CNTs) modified HMA mixtures after fracture tests. According to this figure, the crack has propagated straightly along the initial crack when the specimens are subjected to the pure mode I loading; while, it has propagated along a curvilinear path when the SCB specimens are exposed to the mixed mode and the pure mode II loadings. Because, the maximum tensile stresses near the crack front are not along the initial crack direction when the SCB specimen is exposed to mixed mode or pure mode II loading (Erdogan & Sih, 1963). Furthermore, the fracture initiation angle has increased by increasing the contribution of the shear mode.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this research, asphalt concretes containing binders modified with different percentages (i.e. 0.1%, 0.4%, 0.8% and 1.2%) of Nano Fe2O3 and CNTs were prepared, and fracture experiments were then carried out under different loading modes of I and II. The important results are listed below as follows:
• Experimental results exhibited that as the percentage of Nano Fe2O3 within the HMA mixtures increases, the fracture resistance initially increases to reach its peak value at the
percentage of 0.8%, and then reduces for all loading modes. Hence, the amount of 0.8% is the suitable value for the addition of the Nano Fe2O3 to HMA mixtures. • An improvement of 13% to 27% for the mode I, 8% to 32% for the mixed mode of Me = 0.66 and 3% to 11% for the mixed mode of Me = 0.32 is generally observed depending on the percentage of Nano Fe2O3 used in the HMA mixture. Moreover, the Nano Fe2O3 has a negligible or negative effect on the pure mode II fracture strength of the asphalt concretes. It is also worth mentioning that for the case of pure mode II, the best improvement in fracture strength is 5% for the HMA mixture containing 0.8% Nano Fe2O3 among those modified with Nano Fe2O3. • Fracture properties of asphalt concretes are improved by increasing CNTs content. Hence, the greater CNTs content results in a higher improvement in fracture resistance. • An improvement of 20% to 46% for the pure mode I, 14% to 38% for the mixed mode of Me = 0.66, 3% to 20% for the mixed mode of Me = 0.32 and 0% to 11% for the pure mode II is achieved depending on the CNTs content available in the HMA mixture. Hence, the improvement in fracture strength is more highlighted when the SCB samples made of CNTs-modified HMA mixture are subjected to the pure mode I or the mixed mode I/II loadings that contribution of the mode I is dominant. In other words, as the portion of shear mode at the crack front increases (from pure mode I to pure mode II), the improvement effect of CNTs on the fracture resistance reduces gradually. The highest increase in fracture strength (namely 46%) is achieved for the HMA mixtures modified with 1.2% CNTs under pure mode I. • Although the Nano Fe2O3 increases the fracture resistance of HMA mixtures significantly; however, the fracture strength of HMA mixtures is more improved by the CNTs than the Nano Fe2O3 for the same percentage used in the mixture. • As the amount of shear mode (i.e. mode II) increases (or as the value of Me decreases), fracture resistance of both the Nano Fe2O3 and CNTs modified HMA mixtures initially decreases to reach its minimum value under the loading mode of Me = 0.32, and then increases. This signifies that the HMA mixtures modified with nanomaterials are more vulnerable to the mixed mode I/II fracture than the pure mode I (or II) fracture. Hence, HMA concretes are exposed to the critical conditions of crack growth under the mixed mode I/II loading (i.e Me = 0.32). • According to the fractured SCB specimens, for the case of pure mode I, the crack has propagated along the initial crack; while, it has propagated along a curvilinear path for the mixed mode I/II and pure mode II loadings. Furthermore, the fracture initiation angle has increased with an increase in the proportion of the mode II loading at the crack front.

According to an investigation performed by Aliha (2019) on the mode II fracture toughness of different asphalt mixtures, the mode II fracture toughness of asphalt mixtures (i.e. KIIc) are approximately 0.9–1.1 times the corresponding value of KIc. In another study, Fakhri, Kharrazi, and Aliha (2018) characterised fracture energy of different asphalt mixtures. They concluded that lime aggregate has higher fracture resistance than silica aggregate at low temperatures, while their fracture resistance is approximately the same at intermediate temperatures. Pirmohammad and Kiani (2016a, 2016b) investigated fracture resistance of asphalt mixtures at variable temperature conditions. According to their results, the asphalt mixtures are more vulnerable to crack growth at variable temperature conditions than variable temperature conditions. Aliha and Fattahi Amirdehi (2017) characterised fracture toughness of asphalt mixtures containing different air void contents using Weibull statistical method.

Behbahani, Aliha, Fazaeli, and Aghajani (2013) investigated the effect of different additives such as poly phosphoric acid, styrene butadiene styrene, anti-striping agent, crumb rubber and FT-paraffin wax (Sasobit) on the fracture toughness of asphalt mixtures. Their results show that all the additives improve the fracture toughness of asphalt mixtures, and the highest improvement is achieved by using sasobit and crumb rubber. Aliha, Fakhri, Kharrazi, and Berto (2018) studied the effect of aggregate type and air void on the fracture energy at different temperatures. Aliha, Razmi, and Mansourian (2017) studied the influence of natural and synthetic fibres on fracture resistance of warm mix asphalt (WMA) concretes. The results showed that fibres can significantly improve the fracture resistance of asphalt mixtures. Fakhri, Amoosoltani, and Aliha (2017) investigated the effects of aggregate gradation, cement content, reclaimed asphalt pavement (RAP) and rubber content on the mode I and mode II fracture toughness. The results demonstrated that concrete mix specifications had a significant effect on the cracking initiation of roller compacted concrete (RCC). On the other hand, some interesting investigations have been performed on the mixed mode I/III loading. For example, Ayatollahi, Pirmohammad, and Sedighiani (2014) and Ameri, Mansourian, Khavas, Aliha, and Ayatollahi (2011) showed that the mode III loading cab be a serious threat for the asphalt concrete fracture when a vehicle is positioned at special distances relative to the crack plane. Investigations performed by Aliha, Bahmani, and Akhondi (2016), Pirmohammad and Bayat (2016a, 2016b, 2017), Pirmohammad and Kiani (2016c) and Mansourian, Hashemi, and Aliha (2018) demonstrated that the fracture resistance reduces with increase in the mode III deformations occurred at the crack front.

Many fracture criteria have been also developed in the past years to theoretically predict the fracture behaviour of different engineering materials under mixed mode I/II loading. Maximum tangential stress (suggested by Erdogan & Sih, 1963), generalised maximum tangential stress (suggested by Smith, Ayatollahi, & Pavier, 2001), maximum energy release rate (suggested by Irwin, 1957) and strain energy density (suggested by Sih, 1974) are some to mention a few. For example, Ayatollahi and Aliha (2008) employed the generalised maximum tangential stress criterion for predicting the mixed mode fracture toughness of rock materials tested with the Brazilian disc specimen.

According to Razavi, Aliha, and Berto (2018) and Aliha, Berto, Mousavi, and Razavi (2017), average strain energy density (ASED) criterion is able to provide well predictions for the fracture behaviour of rock materials. Berto and Gomez (2017) suggested two procedures including the strain energy density (SED) over a control volume and the cohesive zone model (CZM) to evaluate fracture resistance of notched components.

According to Razavi, Aliha, and Berto (2018) and Aliha, Berto, Mousavi, and Razavi (2017), average strain energy density (ASED) criterion is able to provide well predictions for the fracture behaviour of rock materials. Berto and Gomez (2017) suggested two procedures including the strain energy density (SED) over a control volume and the cohesive zone model (CZM) to evaluate fracture resistance of notched components. The good agreement between theory and experimental results adds further confidence to the proposed fracture criteria. Nanomaterials are able to improve the mechanical properties of asphalt mixtures (Faramarzi, Arabani, Haghi, & Mottaghitalab, 2015). Recently, application of nanomaterials such as Nano silicon dioxide and Nano titanium (Ye & Chen, 2009), Nano zinc oxide (Sadeghnejad, Arabani, Shakeri, & Mirabdolazimi, 2013), Nano clay (Jahromi & Khodaii, 2009), carbon nanofibres (Khattak, Khattab, Rizvi, & Zhang, 2012), etc. has been widely increased. For example, Shafabakhsh and Ani (2015) showed that the addition of Nano TiO2 and Nano SiO2 to the asphalt mixtures boosts the binder rheological characteristics, and improves their rutting and fatigue resistance.

It is worth noting that Ayatollahi, Aliha, and Saghafi (2011) performed many finite element analyses on a novel SCB specimen containing an edge crack at the middle, which is loading asymmetrically. This specimen can produce different mixed mode I/II loadings by changing the location of supports, whereas the position of the crack is fixed at the middle. The specimen used by Ayatollahi et al. (2011) and that used in this study is different in terms of type of producing mixed mode I/II loading; however, both of these specimens are the same for producing the pure mode I loading.
